3.3 analyze and determine the type of scope required to protect and/or hide data and keep
implementation decoupled from the calling modules and to avoid unwanted side-effects with consideration to:
3.3.1 use of appropriate parameters for importing and exporting data to and from subprograms
3.3.2 use of local variables and nested subprograms to enhance cohesion
3.3.3 one- and two-way parameter passing for importing and exporting data to and from
subprograms
3.4 analyze for, and maintain, an appropriate balance between the coupling or dependency and cohesion or focus of subprograms

Scope to protect and/or hide data, keep implementation decoupled from calling modules, and avoid unwanted side effects. 

Most languages have three scopes for each object:
public, private, and protected.
b
The difference between the 3 isnâ€™t intuitive, so Iâ€™ll illustrate with an example:
Private
b

methods and attributes are hidden within their class, and cannot be accessed by a call from another function. All critical information should be hidden behind the private tag. After all, you donâ€™t want non-users to see user passwords!
Public
b
methods and attributes can be exposed by calling them at any time from another function. Useful for most mundane attributes.
Protected
b
methods and attributes are similar to private attributes, but can be accessed as if they were public from objects derived from that class. Complex, and less frequently used.
For the Connect-4 program, I used
public methods
b

for all of the functions within it, as my program doesnâ€™t contain sensitive information. The ability for me to access object attributes at any time was also extremely helpful for debugging. If my program were more sensitive, or I didnâ€™t want users to see the internal components of my code, I would change my methods to be private.
The core of my program lay in the
board
b

object. Itâ€™s used as the primary input of the win checker, move checker, move executer, and visualization functions. Containing the board position in the form of an array, itâ€™s all that most subprograms need to execute their functions. 

I chose to have
board
b

objects be passed into functions instead of making it a global parameter due to the fact that global parameters heavily slow down performance and become security vulnerabilities in sensitive applications.

The output of each function can be seen in the C++ code, with the string before the function name denoting the type of output. For example,
Board_type
b
place_piece() means that the
place_piece()
i
submodule returns an updated board as output.
Local variables â€” variables within submodules that are
only
i
accessible from those submodules. I used
only
i
local variables (no global variables) to reduce coupling and improve performance.

One or two-way parameter passing â€” all of my functions that check (the win checker, move validity checker) or visualize use one-way parameter passing (in, not out). The only function that changes the board uses two-way parameter passing â€” in for the current board, out for the updated board (after playing a move).
Balance between coupling and focus â€” my code relied on
focus
b
. I intentionally reduced coupling as much as possible to simplify the code and allow for easy modification in the future.
Internal and external documentation â€” This webpage contains both
internal
b
documentation (the comments within the C++ code) and
external
b
documentation (this writeup here).
Eliminating syntax, run-time, and logic errors using
tests.
b
Test 1: Default pieces + Playing a game until its conclusion, with player 1 winning.
Result: Program successfully places pieces in desired locations. It detects the win, announces the winner, and prompts a replay.
Test 2: Default pieces + playing a piece into an already full column.
Result: The program detects the error and prompts a re-move.
Test 3: Default pieces + playing until a draw.
Result: The program behaves as expected â€” it detects the tie, alerting the players with the correct flavor text, and prompts whether the players would like to play again.
Test 4: Custom pieces + playing a game until its conclusion, with player 2 winning.
Result: Program successfully places the custom pieces in desired locations. It detects the win, announces the winner, and prompts a replay.

4. compare the results of the program with the intent of the algorithm and modify, as required
4.1 use appropriate error trapping mechanisms built into the programming environment, as well as programmer-directed error-trapping techniques, to eliminate logic errors and debug the program.
4.2 compare the congruency between the outcomes of the debugged program and the original intent of the algorithm and modify, as required.

An ASCII Connect-4 thatâ€™s playable for two players, without AI support yet. While the graphics might be less sophisticated than what I had originally intended, it serves its function while being a great illustration of modular programming. : )
Eliminating logic errors by conciliating the above two.
Logic errors have been tested and eliminated.
